flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: In this guide we'll take a 120v AC panel mount lamp and convert it to use an LED, allowing it to be powered from DC voltage instead of AC. If you can handle some basic soldering and desoldering, then this should be an easy project!
guide.introduction_rendered:
In this guide we'll take a 120v AC panel mount lamp and convert it to use an LED, allowing it to be powered from DC voltage instead of AC. If you can handle some basic soldering and desoldering, then this should be an easy project!

Relevant parts
  • LED, 5mm, red
  • 120-Volt Neon Red Jumbo Lamp Assembly Radioshack Part #272-710
  • 1/4W 470 ohm resistor
Tools
  • Alligator test/jumper cable set
  • Battery, 9V
  • Desoldering Bulb
  • Helping hands tool with magnifier
  • Soldering iron
  • Wire cutter/stripper

parts.text: 120-Volt Neon Red Jumbo Lamp Assembly Radioshack Part #272-710

parts.notes: You may substitute a different value based on source voltage

lines.text: Lamp assembly - I'm using Radio Shack part #272-710.  It's inexpensive, and easy to take apart, both of which make it great for this project.
lines.text_raw: Lamp assembly - I'm using Radio Shack part #272-710.  It's inexpensive, and easy to take apart, both of which make it great for this project.

lines.text: You don't have to use the Radio Shack lamp.  You may find another assembly that works just as well - maybe in another color.
lines.text_raw: You don't have to use the Radio Shack lamp.  You may find another assembly that works just as well - maybe in another color.

lines.text: Resistor - I'm planning to use my lamp in a 9v DC circuit, so I've selected a 470 ohm resistor.  Assuming a forward voltage of 2v for the LED, this results in 15ma of current through the LED at 9v.
lines.text_raw: Resistor - I'm planning to use my lamp in a 9v DC circuit, so I've selected a 470 ohm resistor.  Assuming a forward voltage of 2v for the LED, this results in 15ma of current through the LED at 9v.

lines.text: If you want to use a different source voltage, you'll need a different resistor. I suggest checking out http://led.linear1.org/led.wiz for help in calculating the needed resistor if you're unsure.
lines.text_raw: If you want to use a different source voltage, you'll need a different resistor.  I suggest checking out http://led.linear1.org/led.wiz for help in calculating the needed resistor if you're unsure.

lines.text: LED - a pretty basic 5mm red LED.
lines.text_raw: LED - a pretty basic 5mm red LED.

lines.text: If using a different lamp assembly, select an LED that matches the color of the assembly's lens.
lines.text_raw: If using a different lamp assembly, select an LED that matches the color of the assembly's lens.

lines.text: To disassemble the lamp assembly, hold the top firmly while twisting the base clockwise.  This unlocks it from the top and you should be able to pull it away now.
lines.text_raw: To disassemble the lamp assembly, hold the top firmly while twisting the base clockwise.  This unlocks it from the top and you should be able to pull it away now.

lines.text: The base will have a resistor and bulb attached to the two solder terminals.  Remove both by desoldering them from the terminals.  There is quite a bit of solder, so a desoldering bulb or pump may work best, but braid may work as well.
lines.text_raw: The base will have a resistor and bulb attached to the two solder terminals.  Remove both by desoldering them from the terminals.  There is quite a bit of solder, so a desoldering bulb or pump may work best, but braid may work as well.

lines.text: The removed bulb and resistor will not be used, and can be saved for other projects or discarded.
lines.text_raw: The removed bulb and resistor will not be used, and can be saved for other projects or discarded.

steps.title: Solder the new resistor and LED in place.

lines.text: Trim the leads on one side of the LED and resistor and solder them together.
lines.text_raw: Trim the leads on one side of the LED and resistor and solder them together.

lines.text: It doesn't matter which sides you trim - but make sure to take note of which side of the LED is the anode and which side is the cathode.  The longer lead is the anode, but this may not be true after trimming!
lines.text_raw: It doesn't matter which sides you trim - but make sure to take note of which side of the LED is the anode and which side is the cathode.  The longer lead is the anode, but this may not be true after trimming!

lines.text: Insert the soldered LED and resistor into the holes on the base where the previous bulb and resistor were installed.  Try to keep the height of the LED about the same as the height of the previous bulb.
lines.text_raw: Insert the soldered LED and resistor into the holes on the base where the previous bulb and resistor were installed.  Try to keep the height of the LED about the same as the height of the previous bulb.

lines.text: If you have trouble inserting the new parts, there may be some solder on the terminal(s) getting in the way, or you may need to bend the terminals to ensure that the leads can get through.
lines.text_raw: If you have trouble inserting the new parts, there may be some solder on the terminal(s) getting in the way, or you may need to bend the terminals to ensure that the leads can get through.

lines.text: Insert the base into the lamp assembly, ensuring that the LED doesn't get stuck and has clearance to fit inside.  Make a mental note of which side is positive (anode) and which side is negative (cathode).
lines.text_raw: Insert the base into the lamp assembly, ensuring that the LED doesn't get stuck and has clearance to fit inside.  Make a mental note of which side is positive (anode) and which side is negative (cathode).

lines.text: With the base firmly in place, twist it counter-clockwise to lock it to the rest of the assembly.
lines.text_raw: With the base firmly in place, twist it counter-clockwise to lock it to the rest of the assembly.

lines.text: Use a black marker or tape to cover the 110-125v voltage specification on the lamp assembly.
lines.text_raw: Use a black marker or tape to cover the 110-125v voltage specification on the lamp assembly.

lines.text: Use a silver marker to mark the housing with the proper source voltage (9v DC in the example) and mark the terminals positive (+) and negative (-).
lines.text_raw: Use a silver marker to mark the housing with the proper source voltage (9v DC in the example) and mark the terminals positive (+) and negative (-).

lines.text: Test the lamp.
lines.text_raw: Test the lamp.

lines.text: Connect the lamp to a power source that provides the needed voltage.
lines.text_raw: Connect the lamp to a power source that provides the needed voltage.

lines.text: Make sure the polarity is correct before powering it on!
lines.text_raw: Make sure the polarity is correct before powering it on!

lines.text: If it lights up, great!  You have a working DC voltage panel lamp.
lines.text_raw: If it lights up, great!  You have a working DC voltage panel lamp.

lines.text: If it doesn't light up, check the polarity - you may have it connected backwards.  If that's not the issue, you'll have to check the soldering - is everything connected properly?
lines.text_raw: If it doesn't light up, check the polarity - you may have it connected backwards.  If that's not the issue, you'll have to check the soldering - is everything connected properly?

guide.summary: Large, jeweled panel mount lamps look cool, but generally are designed for mains (AC) voltage.  Here's a cheap and easy way to convert one for DC usage, for when your project doesn't have mains voltage available.
guide.title: Panel Mount Lamp LED conversion

tools.notes: For connecting power during testing - may use regular wire as well
or other 9v DC power source (for testing)
Optional - use to hold small parts while soldering them together
